Legal_Issue: Whether the trademark owner sufficiently proved use of the POM-POM mark in association with fresh citrus fruits during the relevant period
Procedural_Stage: Appeal from Registrar's decision to the Federal Court
Evidence_Assessment: Affidavits and invoices showing use of the POM-POM mark on citrus fruit packaging sold in Canada were considered sufficient
Burden_of_Proof: On trademark owner to demonstrate use under Section 45
Credibility_Factor: Evidence found credible and reasonably demonstrated use
Legal_Rule: Use under Section 4 includes marking the trademark on goods or packaging at the time of transfer in normal trade
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied by Federal Court
Procedural_Issue: Request for proof of use under Section 45 initiated the proceeding
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged non-use of the trademark during the relevant period
Decision_Maker: Registrar of Trademarks, then Federal Court
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Process followed statutory requirements; no procedural unfairness found
Legal_Framework: Section 45 and Section 4 of the Trade-marks Act
Applicant_Challenge: Argued that evidence of use was insufficient
Defendant_Response: Provided affidavits and invoices to demonstrate use
Remedy_Requested: Cancellation of trademark registration due to non-use
Outcome: Registration maintained; costs awarded to respondent
Resolution_Mechanism: Administrative review followed by judicial appeal
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Non-use of trademark in the relevant period
